dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  Is t possible, friend Litio, that mistress BiancaDoth fancy any other but Lucentio?I tell you, sir, she bears me fair in hand.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Is it possible, my dear friend Litio, that Bianca could prefer another man over me? I tell you, sir, she's been very friendly towards me.

dialogs.original: [as LITIO]  Sir, to satisfy you in what I have said, Stand by and mark the manner of his teaching.  They stand aside
dialogs.translated: [As LITIO] Sir, to prove to you what I've said, stand by right here and watch how this fellow teaches her.

dialogs.original: [as CAMBIO]  Now, mistress, profit you in what you read?
dialogs.translated: [As CAMBIO] Now, mistress, have you been making progress in your studies?

dialogs.original: What, master, read you? First resolve me that.
dialogs.translated: What are you studying, teacher? First answer me that.

dialogs.original: [as CAMBIO]  I read that I profess,  The Art to Love.
dialogs.translated: [As CAMBIO] I study what I teachThe Art of Love.

dialogs.original: And may you prove, sir, master of your art.
dialogs.translated: And may you prove, sir, to be a master of your art.

dialogs.original: [as CAMBIO]  While you, sweet dear, prove mistress of my heart!
dialogs.translated: [As CAMBIO] While you, sweet dear, prove to be the mistress of my heart!

dialogs.original: [as LITIO]  Quick proceeders, marry! Now, tell me, I pray,You that durst swear that your mistress BiancaLoved none in the world so well as Lucentio.
dialogs.translated: [As LITIO] How quickly he earns his degree! Now tell me, please, what just happened? I thought you swore that your mistress Bianca loved no one in the world better than Lucentio.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  O despiteful love! Unconstant womankind! I tell thee, Litio, this is wonderful!
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Oh spiteful love! Faithless womankind! I tell you, Litio, it's incredible!

dialogs.original: Mistake no more. I am not Litio,    Nor a musician as I seem to be,    But one that scorn to live in this disguise    For such a one as leaves a gentleman    And makes a god of such a cullion.    Know, sir, that I am called Hortensio.
dialogs.translated: Let me reveal myself. I am not Litio, and not a musician either. I refuse to continue with this disguise for the sake of a woman who would choose a low-class scoundrel over a gentleman like me. Know, sir, that I am called Hortensio.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]   Signior Hortensio, I have often heard    Of your entire affection to Bianca,    And since mine eyes are witness of her lightness,    I will with you, if you be so contented,    Forswear Bianca and her love for ever.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Sir Hortensio, I've often heard of your sincere affection for Bianca, and now that I've seen with my own eyes that she is unfaithful, I will join you, if you like, in rejecting Bianca and her love forever.

dialogs.original: See how they kiss and court!   Signior Lucentio,    Here is my hand, and here I firmly vow    Never to woo her more,   but do forswear her    As one unworthy all the former favors    That I have fondly flattered her withal.
dialogs.translated: See how they kiss and flirt! Sir Lucentio, take my hand. I firmly vow to stop wooing her forever. I reject her as a woman unworthy of all the time and money I have so foolishly flattered her with.

dialogs.original: And here I take the like unfeignèd oathNever to marry with her, though she would entreat.Fie on her! See how beastly she doth court him!
dialogs.translated: And I now make the same oath, never to marry her even if she begs me. Damn her! See how lustfully she flirts with him!

dialogs.original: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn!    For me, that I may surely keep mine oath,    I will be married to a wealthy widow,    Ere three days pass,   which hath as long loved me    As I have loved this proud disdainful haggard.    And so farewell, Signior Lucentio.    Kindness in women, not their beauteous looks,    Shall win my love,   and so I take my leave,    In resolution as I swore before.
dialogs.translated: I wish all the world but him would reject her, so she'd have only that poor schoolteacher to accept her as a wife! But as for me, I will surely keep my promise. I plan to marry a wealthy widow before three days have passed. She's been in love with me for as long as I've been pursuing this proud, disdainful vixen. And so farewell, Sir Lucentio. From now on, kindness in women, not their beauty, will win my love. And so I bid you farewell, and am resolved to keep my promise.

dialogs.original: Mistress Bianca, bless you with such grace    As 'longeth to a lovers blessèd case!    Nay, I have ta'en you napping, gentle love,    And have forsworn you with Hortensio.
dialogs.translated: Miss Bianca, may you be blessed with all the good fortune you deserve! No, I've caught you napping, my dear. Both Hortensio and I have rejected you.

dialogs.original: Tranio, you jest. But have you both forsworn me?
dialogs.translated: You're joking, Tranio! But have you both really given me up?

dialogs.original: Mistress, we have.
dialogs.translated: Mistress, we have.

dialogs.original: Then we are rid of Litio.
dialogs.translated: Then we've gotten rid of Litio.

dialogs.original: I' faith, hell have a lusty widow nowThat shall be wooed and wedded in a day.
dialogs.translated: Yes, now he'll have a lively widow for himself. He claims he'll woo her and marry her in a day.

dialogs.original: God give him joy!
dialogs.translated: God give him joy!

dialogs.original: Ay, and hell tame her.
dialogs.translated: Yes, and he'll tame her.

dialogs.original: He says so, Tranio?
dialogs.translated: Did he say that, Tranio?

dialogs.original: Faith, he is gone unto the taming school.
dialogs.translated: Well, he's gone off to the taming school.

dialogs.original: The taming school? What, is there such a place?
dialogs.translated: The taming school? What, is there such a place?

dialogs.original: Ay, mistress, and Petruchio is the master,That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty longTo tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.
dialogs.translated: Yes, mistress, and Petruchio is the headmaster. He teaches suitable tricks to tame a shrew and her chattering tongue.

dialogs.original: O master, master, I have watched so long    That I am dog-weary, but at last I spied    An ancient angel coming down the hill    Will serve the turn.
dialogs.translated: Oh master, master, I've been watching for so long that I'm dog-tired, but at last I spied a good old fellow coming down the hill. He'll work for our needs.

dialogs.original: What is he, Biondello?
dialogs.translated: Who is he, Biondello?

dialogs.original: Master, a marcantant, or a pedant, I know not what, but formal in apparel,In gait and countenance surely like a father.
dialogs.translated: Master, I'm not sure if he's a merchant or a schoolmaster, but he's well-dressed and looks old and respectable enough to be Lucentio's father.

dialogs.original: And what of him, Tranio?
dialogs.translated: And what will you do with him, Tranio?

dialogs.original: If he be credulous and trust my tale,    Ill make him glad to seem Vincentio    And give assurance to Baptista Minola    As if he were the right Vincentio.    Take in your love, and then let me alone.
dialogs.translated: If he's gullible and believes my story, then I'll make him happy to pretend to be Vincentio and vouch for you to Baptista Minola, just as if he were the real Vincentio. Take your sweetheart and leave this to me.

dialogs.original: God save you, sir.
dialogs.translated: Hello and God bless you, sir.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]   And you, sir. You are welcome.Travel you far on, or are you at the farthest?
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] And you too, sir. Welcome. Are you going farther, or is this your destination?

dialogs.original: Sir, at the farthest for a week or two,But then up farther, and as far as Rome,And so to Tripoli, if God lend me life.
dialogs.translated: Sir, this is my destination for a week or two, but then I'll go on as far as Rome, and then to Tripoli, if God is willing.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  What countryman, I pray?
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Where are you from, if I might ask?

dialogs.original: Of Mantua.
dialogs.translated: From Mantua.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  Of Mantua, sir? Marry, God forbid! And come to Padua, careless of your life?
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Mantua, sir? God forbid! And you've come to Padua? Are you so careless with your life?

dialogs.original: My life, sir! how, I pray? For that goes hard.
dialogs.translated: My life, sir! What do you mean? That sounds serious indeed.

dialogs.original: 'Tis death for anyone in Mantua    To come to Padua. Know you not the cause?    Your ships are stayed at Venice, and the Duke,    For private quarrel twixt your duke and him,    Hath published and proclaimed it openly.    'Tis marvel, but that you are but newly come,    You might have heard it else proclaimed about.
dialogs.translated: It's death for anyone from Mantua to come to Padua. Don't you know why? The Duke of Padua proclaimed it openly. There's a private quarrel between him and your duke, and all the ships from Mantua are being impounded in Venice. It's amazing that you didn't know, but I guess you just arrived. Otherwise you would have heard it proclaimed all around town.

dialogs.original: Alas, sir, it is worse for me than so, For I have bills for money by exchangeFrom Florence, and must here deliver them.
dialogs.translated: Alas, sir, this is bad news for me. I have money orders from Florence, and I must deliver them here.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  Well, sir, to do you courtesy,This will I do, and this I will advise you.First tell me, have you ever been at Pisa?
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Well, sir, I'll do you a favor, and help you out and give you some advice. But first tell me, have you ever been to Pisa?

dialogs.original: Ay, sir, in Pisa have I often been,Pisa renownèd for grave citizens.
dialogs.translated: Yes, sir, I've often been to PisaPisa, famous for its serious citizens.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  Among them know you one Vincentio?
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Do you know one of those citizens called Vincentio?

dialogs.original: I know him not, but I have heard of him:A merchant of incomparable wealth.
dialogs.translated: I don't know him, but I've heard of him: a merchant of incomparable wealth.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  He is my father, sir, and sooth to say,In count'nance somewhat doth resemble you.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] He is my father, sir, and to be honest, you look a little bit like him.

dialogs.original: [aside]  As much as an apple doth an oyster, and all one.
dialogs.translated: [To himself] As much as an apple looks like an oyster, but that's no matter.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]   To save your life in this extremity,    This favor will I do you for his sake    And think it not the worst of all your fortunes    That you are like to Sir Vincentio    His name and credit shall you undertake,    And in my house you shall be friendly lodged.    Look that you take upon you as you should.    You understand me, sir.   So shall you stay    Till you have done your business in the city.    If this be courtsy, sir, accept of it.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] I'll do you this favor for his sake, and to save your life in this dangerous situationindeed, you should consider yourself lucky that you resemble Sir Vincentio. You'll pretend to be him, assume his name and reputation, and stay at my house as a guest. Just make sure that you play your part well. Do you understand, sir? This way you can stay until you've done your business in the city. If this is kindness, then accept it.

dialogs.original: O sir, I do, and will repute you ever The patron of my life and liberty.
dialogs.translated: Oh sir, I will, and I'll always consider you the savior of my life and liberty.

dialogs.original: (as    LUCENTIO    )    Then go with me to make the matter good.    This, by the way, I let you understand:    My father is here looked for every day    To pass assurance of a dower in marriage    'Twixt me and one Baptistas daughter here.    In all these circumstances Ill instruct you.    Go with me to clothe you as becomes you.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Then come with me, and we'll get everything ready. By the way, I should also tell you this: my father is expected here any day now to come vouch for me about a widow's inheritance for my marriage. The marriage contract is between me and the daughter of a man named Baptista, who lives here. I'll instruct you about the rest of the details. Come with me, and I'll get you some new clothes.
